children.subject:
I'll also mention that as a hardware person who isn't into machine learning whatsoever, 127 was a little strange.

Even though it's historically an EE class, it's been "sanitized" of any EE references. For example, in 120, even though LTI systems are clearly not limited in scope to electric circuitry, the systems are presented mostly in the context of analog circuits, even though general math principles are still taught.

You would expect an optimization class in the EE department to teach this math in the context of obvious applications like component placement in VLSI and MIMO systems, but the department seems to have relented and cleaned its optimization class of anything hardware-related in order to make it more appealing to the CS people.

Yeah, sanitized is a good way to put it, and something similar goes for 126. Both classes are super applicable to just about anything, but the applications chosen recently seem to have been selected to almost appease the majority demographic of students. It kind of reflects what seems to be the department's position that hardware isn't really where it's at anymore (which is why 16AB provide such poor preparation for the semiconductor and circuits upper divs).

I can't really answer most of this question in an informed way myself, but I'd recommend reaching out to Profs. Pilawa (pilawa@berkeley.edu) and/or von Meier (vonmeier@eecs.berkeley.edu) about these specific questions. I think they're both fairly receptive to advising undergrads (whether in course planning or research). On that note, you should definitely look into working on research/applied projects with one or both of them.

As for EECS 127 and 149 in particular, I think they could both be fairly useful, although one should note that 127 is basically just a math class and 149 is heavily lab/project oriented. If you want to go to grad school in the areas you've specified, you'd probably end up doing both (eventually). None of the classes you've mentioned seem like "software" classes to me (except 149 and occasional iPython notebook assignments in the other classes aside).

history.content:
Hi everyone (especially power & energy enthusiasts)!

As an EE - and specifically power & energy systems - focused student, I am currently trying to decide between the hardware and software paths in power systems engineering. I want to take classes that would make me suitable for jobs in both paths after graduation (or for a masters degree).

I would definitely love to work on SCADA/EMS/DMS as an entry level power systems engineer, and I am looking at the course options that would reinforce the power systems optimization & control aspects, besides the transmission & distribution part that I will already learn about. 

Long story short, after taking EE 105, EE 120, EE 122, EE 137A, and EE 137B, would it be reasonable to take EE 113, EE C128 and EECS 127? I particularly cannot decide between EECS 127 and EECS 149, as I don't have much knowledge about which course is more suitable and can be applied to control algorithms in power or energy systems. 

Any insight will be much appreciated, thanks!
history.subject: Power Systems Engineering: Hardware or Software? (Or... both?)
